qas.question: What is the main source of starch and most beer?
At what point does barley have it's hull broken up into pieces?
What takes the place of barley malt in gluten-free beer?
When is sweet wort separated during the brewing process?
Aside from barley, what is a another product founded beer that might contain gluten?
What does all beer include as the majority of malt?
What is done to the barley after it is milled?
What do the remaining grain pieces act as during lautering?
What is the beer containing wheat, barley, and rye called when made with sorghum as well?

context: Nearly all beer includes <a0_0>barley malt<a0_0/> as the majority of the <b5_0>starch<b5_0/>. This is because its fibrous hull remains attached to the grain during threshing. <a1_0>After <b6_0>malting<b6_0/><a1_0/>, barley is milled, which finally removes the hull, breaking it into large pieces. These pieces remain with the grain during the mash, and act as a <b7_0>filter bed<b7_0/> <a3_0>during lautering<a3_0/>, when sweet wort is separated from insoluble grain material. Other malted and unmalted grains (including wheat, rice, oats, and rye, and less frequently, corn and sorghum) may be used. Some brewers have produced <b8_0>gluten-free beer<b8_0/>, made with <a2_0>sorghum<a2_0/> with no barley malt, for those who cannot consume gluten-containing grains like <a4_0>wheat<a4_0/>, barley, and rye.
